unnormalised: A few years back, I remember Amma stressing about opening a new bank account. She’d been using the same account at SBI for 30+ years, but the branch was becoming inaccessible for her. So, we decided to switch. The process felt unnecessarily complicated back then; multiple forms, KYC documents (Aadhar no. 4789-2345-9876 being the most crucial), and endless waiting in queues.
normalised: A few years back, I remember Amma stressing about opening a new bank account. She’d been using the same account at S-B-I for thirty plus years, but the branch was becoming inaccessible for her. So, we decided to switch. The process felt unnecessarily complicated back then; multiple forms, K-Y-C documents (Aadhar number four thousand seven hundred and eighty nine dash two thousand three hundred and forty five dash nine thousand eight hundred and seventy six being the most crucial), and endless waiting in queues.

unnormalised: We finally opted for a private bank, HDFC, thinking the service would be better. The initial experience was indeed smoother; they even offered a 'premium' account with slightly higher interest rates, like 7.5% p.a. I distinctly recall the relationship manager, Mr. Sharma, explaining the benefits. He showed us various options for fixed deposits starting from ₹5000.
normalised: We finally opted for a private bank, H-D-F-C, thinking the service would be better. The initial experience was indeed smoother; they even offered a 'premium' account with slightly higher interest rates, like seven point five percent per annum. I distinctly recall the relationship manager, Mister Sharma, explaining the benefits. He showed us various options for fixed deposits starting from rupee five thousand.

unnormalised: Then came the UPI revolution. Suddenly, everyone was using Google Pay and PhonePe for even the smallest transactions. Paying the local chai wala Rs. 10 became commonplace. Even Amma, initially resistant, started using Paytm to pay the electricity bill, which usually amounted to Rs. 2500-3000 per month.
normalised: Then came the U-P-I revolution. Suddenly, everyone was using Google Pay and PhonePe for even the smallest transactions. Paying the local chai wala rupees ten became commonplace. Even Amma, initially resistant, started using Paytm to pay the electricity bill, which usually amounted to rupees two thousand five hundred to three thousand per month.

unnormalised: However, managing multiple accounts became a headache. Remembering different passwords and transaction limits was a constant struggle. I once accidentally transferred ₹10000 to the wrong account because I mixed up the account numbers. It took days to sort out with the bank, and I had to fill out form no. 47B.
normalised: However, managing multiple accounts became a headache. Remembering different passwords and transaction limits was a constant struggle. I once accidentally transferred rupee ten thousand to the wrong account because I mixed up the account numbers. It took days to sort out with the bank, and I had to fill out form number forty seven B.

unnormalised: Recently, I decided to consolidate my accounts. After comparing interest rates and service charges across several banks (ICICI, Axis, and Kotak Mahindra), I chose to maintain only two accounts. One for daily transactions and another high-yield savings account offering 6.85% interest rate.
normalised: Recently, I decided to consolidate my accounts. After comparing interest rates and service charges across several banks (I-C-I-C-I, Axis, and Kotak Mahindra), I chose to maintain only two accounts. One for daily transactions and another high-yield savings account offering six point eight five percent interest rate.

unnormalised: It’s funny how much banking has changed. From Amma’s single SBI account to managing multiple digital wallets and high-yield options, it feels like a completely different world. I wonder what the future holds, maybe everything will be handled by AI by 2030!
